lines: Application
MR CATCHPOLE:  Sir, before we resume, there is an
application in relation to additions to the bundle and
disclosure, which I'm making.
I wonder whether I can explain it this way.  If we
could just have up on the screen, please, Mr Bradley's
report, first report, C1, page 251.
This is in Mr Bradley's report.  Section 8.20, he's
dealing with the cause of critical delay to one of
the -- what he says is a critical element at this stage,
the hotel towers.  In paragraph 8.20.2, he says:
"The period of the design issues, along with its
effects on the progress ... are discussed in SBJV's
letter to the Engineer dated 10 October 2019 ..."
Just note that date.
He then sets out a quote which lists a whole load of
correspondence and there are I think 44 letters there
between myself, my clients and DEC, stemming from
21 September 2017, right the way to the date of
10 October.
Over the page, Mr Bradley has underlined,
highlighted various bits, but in the passage with the
first underlining, he said:
"We had previously enclosed letter from the ...
Subcontractor, Specon ... dated 20th November 2017."
So that's a common document.
Then Mr Bradley identifies that this correspondence
he says relates to:
"... details of how shop drawings have been rejected
as a consequence of the issued IFC documents having
a lack of information."
So his essential thrust is, as I understand it: all
of this correspondence ongoing, SBJV are accepting that
there are problems with revisions having to be done to
the shop drawings for the purposes, because of revised
IFC documents.
If one goes down to 8.20.3, he says:
"In summary, in view of SBJV's letter above [so he's
relying directly on it] I understand that:
"i. Specon issued letters to SBJV starting from
November 2017 regarding the effects of the missing
information in IFCs on the approval of the shop
drawings."
And that that whole chain entitled SBJV to an
extension of time:
"iii. The effects of the IFC issues were ongoing as
of 10 October ..."
So the whole thing is still going on:
"As per the SBJV's letter [that's 10 October], the
figure below shows the period during which SBJV issued
48 letters ..."
Which are all the letters he's listed, and he has
a figure.
He then goes on, over some time, to look at various
revisions to the shop drawings which are made, and his
conclusion ultimately is that they are the cause of
critical delay, by reference to that.
If one goes forward -- I hear my learned friend
sighing, but if one goes forward, please, to page
C1-277, you see, for example, he says in 8.20.55:
"In my opinion, the cause of critical delay ... was
the slow progress of ... Clearance ... which appears to
be attributable to the extensive revisions implemented
to the IFC drawings ...
"I understand that the effects of late finalisation
of design on the issuance of MEP Clearance ... continued
beyond ...
"The effect of [that is] ..."
Then he goes straight back to the letter of
10 October 2019.
If we come back to C1-251, my understanding,
certainly reading this -- could we go down a little bit
to paragraph 8.20.2, so we can see the text; keep going,
please -- is that what Mr Bradley is saying is that all
of this correspondence is ongoing over a period of
two years and is still going; it relates to extensive
revisions to the IFC design causing revisions to the
shop drawings, and then it goes on.  And I would like to
ask him a few questions about the correspondence.
So I asked the simple question, where are they in
the bundle, in the course of preparing
cross-examination, to which the answer is, they're not
there.  And it turns out that these letters are our
letters to DEC, which have not previously been
disclosed, so one assumes Mr Bradley has never seen
them, apart from, of course, if you go over the page,
please, the common letter of 20 November 2017.
But I would still like to -- if that's right, and
I had not appreciated that; if that's right, obviously
I want to discuss with Mr Bradley how he came to form
opinions based on correspondence that he didn't see, but
also, given what he's saying about this and what he
infers from these letters, to look at what is actually
being discussed in that correspondence.
So last night, we collected those letters and
disclosed the ones that had not previously been
disclosed and asked them to be added to the bundle and
there was an objection to that, which, with the greatest
respect to my learned friend and his solicitors, I don't
understand, since it's their own expert who is actually
deploying them.
MR HICKEY:  I do object.  The simple fact of the matter, as
Mr Catchpole has just admitted, in the course of trying
to do some preparation for his cross-examination, he has
identified a letter which refers to other letters which
have never been disclosed by them, they're not documents
that we've looked at, because it's been quoted in
a letter that deals with the subject matter.
He now wishes to use them.  They were in -- this
quote was in my expert's first report, I can't remember
how long ago that was, that was a long time ago.
Mr Coyne doesn't refer to these letters, so nobody has
referred to these letters.
They've never been disclosed.  I have had no advance
warning, not even advance warning of this application,
and it's far too late in the day to be trying to
introduce new evidence at the last minute that my expert
hasn't himself considered.
All that's happened is he's picked upon a letter
that refers to other letters that are not common
letters, they're not letters that we have had.  He is
not relying on those 48 letters, he's simply quoting
a letter that says: during this period, I note that
they've been writing letters, but this is what happened.
PRESIDENT:  But isn't he relying on the summary in the
letter that he set out in his report to conclude that
the 44 letters were of a particular kind?
MR HICKEY:  No, he's not doing that.  By all means,
Mr Catchpole can ask that question, but one doesn't need
to have the letters to justify whatever it is they're
going to do.
The application as I understand it is not confined
to these whatever letters, 44 letters.  As I understand
it, the application is to introduce 133 letters from the
respondent to the engineer and a further seven -- well,
I'm only quoting what I've been told.
MR CATCHPOLE:  I think --
MR HICKEY:  That's what I have been told.  If you would let
me finish my submissions.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Can I just clarify, Mr Hickey, the only
application being made is to have disclosed and put in
the bundle the letters that are referred to in this.
I think what you may --
MR HICKEY:  How many are there?
PRESIDENT:  Just to be clear, Mr Catchpole, is this the
letters referred to --
MR CATCHPOLE:  In this letter of --
PRESIDENT:  -- in paragraph 8.20.2?
MR CATCHPOLE:  Exactly right.
I'm sorry, Mr Hickey, just to be clear, I think the
problem may be if you're counting letters that --
letters will enclose other letters.
MR HICKEY:  There you are.
MR CATCHPOLE:  These are the ones --
MR HICKEY:  So how many do you want?
MR CATCHPOLE:  Whatever is referred to in this, for a matter
of fairness, I would like to have disclosed in full.
PRESIDENT:  Including --
MR CATCHPOLE:  Whatever is enclosed with them.
PRESIDENT:  So just the fact that a letter is referred to in
this letter doesn't mean that you want it in, though,
does it?  It has to be enclosed with the letter or --
MR CATCHPOLE:  Yes, yes, of course.
PRESIDENT:  So it's not just referred to.
MR CATCHPOLE:  No, no, no, no.  Sorry, no.
PRESIDENT:  Letters with enclosures.
MR CATCHPOLE:  That are referred to in this particular
letter.
MR HICKEY:  I'm told that they want 133 letters.  Please can
you clarify exactly the number of letters you want.
MR CATCHPOLE:  I will tell you now, absolutely, all I want,
whatever letter is referred to in --
MR HICKEY:  How many letters please Mr Catchpole?
MR CATCHPOLE:  They are, I believe, 48 letters plus the
common document with whatever is attached to those
letters.
MR HICKEY:  How many of those?
MR CATCHPOLE:  I do not know, Mr Hickey, because I am not
working on the basis of undisclosed documents at the
moment.  All I want to do is get them into the bundle so
I can consider them with Mr Bradley if I think that's
right.
MR HICKEY:  Well, it's totally unfair and I'm completely
prejudiced because I have not seen these letter.  I'm
going to have no opportunity to see these letters.
That's a lot of letters to read when I'm trying to
prepare my cross-examination.
PRESIDENT:  When will Mr Bradley be called to give evidence?
MR HICKEY:  This afternoon.
MR CATCHPOLE:  I'm happy for him to talk through.
PRESIDENT:  This issue could be stood over until tomorrow
morning, couldn't it, he's likely to be in the box
tomorrow morning.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Yes.
PRESIDENT:  So you could review them tonight.
Anything else, Mr Hickey?
MR HICKEY:  No, sir.
PRESIDENT:  Anything in reply, Mr Catchpole?
MR CATCHPOLE:  Only that, with the greatest respect to my
learned friend, if one rereads 8.20.4, Mr Bradley is
positively asserting that the correspondence that's
referred to in that letter, issued 48 letters regarding,
and it's those letters that he's referring to.  It is
absolutely wrong, with the greatest respect, to suggest
otherwise.
PRESIDENT:  Gentlemen, the tribunal's view is that the
application at the moment is to put the documents in
a bundle, so they can be referred to.  We grant that
application on the basis that the relevance of the
documents will remain to be tested.  So that if
Mr Bradley, for example, says that he doesn't rely upon
the content of any of those documents for the conclusion
that he's drawn, then it would appear then that the
documents will be irrelevant; but if on the other hand
Mr Bradley says he does rely on the tenor of the
documents as represented in the summary letter in his
report for his conclusion, then they will be relevant.
But if, Mr Hickey, you're prejudiced by the lateness of
the introduction of these documents, we can stand that
portion of Mr Bradley's evidence over until tomorrow, by
which time you should have had an opportunity to review
the documents.
Is that clear then, gentlemen?
MR HICKEY:  That's clear and fair.  I'm grateful for that.
Thank you.
PRESIDENT:  If those documents could be loaded up by as soon
as possible, certain by close of play today, so that
Mr Hickey and his team can review them tonight.
MR HICKEY:  Could they be put in a separate -- so that I can
identify them, could they be put in a separate series so
that I can easily find them.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Of course, yes.
PRESIDENT:  Marked for the attention of Mr Hickey.
MR WILLIAM HAGGART
PRESIDENT:  Mr Haggart, I'm sorry for that distraction to
your evidence.
A.  That's quite okay.
PRESIDENT:  I'm sure you don't need me to remind you that
the oath that you gave yesterday remains in force, and
I'll ask Mr Catchpole now to cross-examine you -- oh,
Mr Kazmi.
Cross-examination by MR KAZMI
MR KAZMI:  Mr Haggart, thank you for sitting through that.
You're a seasoned expert, you know how these things
work.
A.  It's never the same.
Q.  Yes, of course.  Time is a bit tight and what I'm going
to try and do, I'm going to start by asking some
questions about your general approach and the approach
that you've adopted throughout your five reports, and
then I'm going to ask a few questions about the
conclusions you reach in respect of each of those and,
as far as possible, for all of our sakes, I'm going to
try and do that in the order of your reports.
A.  Sure.
Q.  So, first report is hotel, second report is podium, and
then we go on to deal with technical issues.
Just to ground ourselves, could we please have up
A3-51.  That's from the statement of claim in these
proceedings it's paragraph 130.  This was served on
25 February 2023.
This is Specon's pleading in which we can see:
"Specon intends to submit a comprehensive analysis
of all such delays in due course by way of expert
evidence.  For present purposes, Specon has summarised
below are some of the key impacts of ... design-related
failings ..."
Then if you go down, you can see at 130(b) -- well,
there's a whole list going down a few pages, but just
look at 130(b).  It identifies:
"... abortive engineering works as a result of the
IFC Drawings deficiencies and SBJV continually revising
and re-issuing the IFC Drawings."
That's one of the things that Specon complains about
in the statement of claim.
A.  Yes.
Q.  Had you been instructed at this stage, Mr Haggart?
A.  I was instructed in around January 2024, I believe, or
maybe a month or two beforehand.  So I don't quite know
how that date aligns with the --
Q.  This is April 2023, so this is about eight months before
then?
A.  Yes.
Q.  As far as you're aware, when the statement of claim was
drafted, was there another expert acting for Specon or
was this something that they produced on their own
without any expert input?
A.  I'm not aware of any other expert.
Q.  Let's just track this through.  We respond to this
in October.  A9-115 is our plea in response to this
pleading.  It's our statement of defence and
counterclaim.
Paragraphs (d) and (e) are responding to what we
were just looking at.
We deny:
"... abortive engineering works as a result of
alleged issues ..."
And the reason we state is:
"... because Specon has not demonstrated what work
it had progressed or completed by the time that revised
or allegedly late IFC Drawings were issued, such that it
would subsequently be rendered abortive or needed to be
reworked ..."
Then at (e):
"... apart from a handful of letters, Specon
provides no contemporaneous records in support of its
speculative assertions."
Then just to track that through, in December we have
a reply to this pleading, that's A28-76,
paragraph 296(f) of the reply.  That's replying to the
two passages we just looked at.  It says:
"... Specon will provide a full critical path
analysis and [separately] evidence as to the extent of
abortive work caused by design changes..."
So, as you said in your presentation yesterday,
you're not here for the critical path analysis bit of
things, but "evidence as to the extent of abortive work
caused by design changes, by factual and expert
evidence", that's I believe where you come into the
picture; is that right?
A.  Yes, as I stated yesterday, I didn't do any granular
analysis of the quantum of those impacts.
Q.  What's said here is that our:
"... denial that design changes caused abortive work
is unsustainable in light of ... the recorded fact that
more than 10,000 shop drawings were superseded and
reissued due to design changes."
Then the footnote 80 is a shop drawing register to
which we'll return in due course.
It's around this time that you get instructed, and
you get --
A.  Yes.
Q.  -- instructed to look at the impact of these design
changes for the purposes set out there?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Your instruction to look at other aspects of MEP, the
wild air, the leaks and insulation, that came at a later
stage?
A.  That followed, yes.
Q.  We're going to look into sort of impact in a minute, but
could I just understand some principles of impact of
change.
Whether or not a change to design has an impact,
that's to be looked at in light of a number of things.
For instance, what that change is, the nature of the
change itself?
A.  Yes.
Q.  We need to see where that change is?
A.  Yes.
Q.  So both locally within a system and broadly within the
project as a whole?
A.  Yes.
Q.  We also need to look at when that change is?
A.  That would be evident from the issue of the drawing,
I would suggest, yes.
Q.  But by "when", in respect of what was the progress of
the engineering at that point in time?
A.  Yes, indeed.
Q.  So whether shop drawings had been progressed or not,
whether procurement had been progressed or not, things
of that sort?
A.  Yes.
Q.  So there's one aspect of awareness, just looking at the
date, and the other is looking at other dates and
matching that up?
A.  Yes, that's a very binary way of looking at it, because
it doesn't take into consideration what goes on in the
background, but in principle, yes.
Q.  Of course, and that's the other thing you need to look
at, which is what's going on in the background?
A.  Yes.
Q.  So you need to therefore look at what's going on on the
project as a whole when a particular change comes in?
A.  Yes.
Q.  The nature of MEP activities is that by their very
nature, they require quite a bit of coordination, don't
they?
A.  They do, yes.
Q.  So you have the first fixes, then you have the second
fixes and then you have the testing and commissioning
and things of that sort?
A.  Yes, that's not coordination, that's a sequence of --
Q.  There's two things: there's a sequence of things?
A.  Yes.
Q.  But because that sequence involves, between the first
fix and the second fix, others coming and doing other
things, there needs to be an element of coordination as
well, doesn't there?
A.  Between what?  Sorry.  I don't understand the question.
Q.  So there's a sequence of works?
A.  Yes.
Q.  And within that sequence of works, the MEP installer
hands over to others and then picks up from others?
A.  Yes.
Q.  There's that one aspect of sequencing --
A.  That's the installation works, yes.
Q.  In the installation.  Just for my own understanding, can
you just help me: as sort of a rule of thumb, at what
stage of sort of the first, second fixes would you
expect to see testing and commissioning activities
commence?
A.  Testing and commissioning is usually the final, in the
final sequence of work.  The systems are installed,
first and second fix is complete, third fix is even
complete, for the majority of the testing and
commissioning to be done.
A number of dead tests can be done in advance of
final fix, such as insulation resistance testing of
cabling for example or pressure testing of discrete
sections of pipework that have been installed.  But the
final commissioning and testing cannot be completed
until the installation is completed.
Q.  When you've got your first and second fix, is it sort of
the -- on a whole, 60, 70 per cent level, you can start
looking at testing and things of that sort?
A.  Again, that's quite a binary view of things.  One would
need to look at individual systems, what level of
advancement they were at.  As I said, pieces of systems
could be tested and commissioned, but not completely.
The final testing and commissioning could not be
completed until the installation was fully completed.
Q.  That's fair.  I'm just trying to understand at the level
of the job that we have.
You then wrote two reports dealing with design
change.  Your instructions for those reports are in the
joint statement at C139-5 and C139-6.
You have your first report, which is effectively
hotel towers, as you said yesterday?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Your instructions, if we just look at sort of window 1,
is:
"consider the revised electrical and mechanical ...
drawings ... and [assess] whether there was any impact
on Specon's ability to progress with the MEP works in
the Hotel Towers ..."
A.  Yes.
Q.  The same at sort of window 2, you'll see:
"consider what Subcontract Works ... have been
impacted ..."
And then again:
"... impact on MEP clearances ... and ... impact on
the provision of the shop drawings."
A.  Yes.
Q.  Same with window 3 and window 4 and so on.
Then if we look over the page on your second report,
please go down -- sorry, go down, C139-6, perfect.
Your instructions here are in respect of the podium
and opine on how the design developed throughout the
podium.  Again, you're looking at the impact of the
design changes in the podium, yes?
A.  Sorry, I lost your direction there.  Are we at point 7
on that page?
Q.  Yes, if we could just look at point 7.
A.  Yes.
Q.  Now, when you were instructed in January 2024 or
thereabouts, were you instructed only to look at the
hotel at that stage or was it that you ended up doing
two reports because you didn't have the time to do both
hotel and podium in the first report in April?
A.  I don't recall at all, sir.  I took it as it came, my
first set of instructions and a second set of
instructions.
Q.  You got two sets of instructions?
A.  Yes.
Q.  One set of instruction related to the hotel?
A.  Yes.
Q.  And then you got another set of instructions that
related to the podium?
A.  The first set of instructions I think wasn't just the
hotel, it was the general design progress, if I recall
correctly.
Q.  Could we just scroll back up, please, to the first
report.  I can see the general design progress under
project 211, but where in the summary do we find -- and
where in your report do we find you covering things that
are not the hotel?
A.  This is perhaps -- it may be helpful to the tribunal if
we refer to my first report.  I'm fairly sure I set out
my instructions there.  That might be a more accurate --
Q.  Absolutely, we'll look at that in just a minute, but
what I understand is you've done two reports.  One is
a hotel impact report and the other is a podium impact
report.  I just want to understand for the tribunal when
their trying to assess the impact at a point in time,
they've got to look at both -- they've got to overlay
the two reports and then look at the factual evidence of
what's happening on site at the same time?
A.  Yes.
Q.  It's not something that can be looked at by just one --
the first report or the second report in isolation.
It's the two reports overlaid on top of each other with
the facts looked at --
A.  I think a better way to look at the structure of the
reports is the first report was a more generic approach
to the design process and the second report homed in on
a dozen or so specific areas in the podium.
Q.  Just so that I understand, why was it that you were
unable to do what you did in the second report, in the
first report?
A.  I wasn't instructed to.
Q.  At January 2024, you were only instructed to do
a general review, which you did in your first report?
A.  In relation to the impact of the IFC design on I think
it was five discrete windows that had been identified,
look at these windows and assess the impact of design in
each of these windows.
Q.  I see, because I had understood that when you were
instructed in January, you were instructed to look at
design changes as a whole, because that's what those
bits of the pleading we looked at said they were --
A.  I think that's what I'm saying, it was a general design
progress and process as a whole in my first report and
then homing in on, as I said, a dozen or so discrete
areas in my second report.
Q.  I see, can you help me with this.  When were you
instructed first to look at the podium?
A.  I don't recall.
Q.  Was it after your first report was finalised?
A.  After it was finalised, I don't think so, but again my
second report should have -- might have -- the date on
which my instructions were given.
Q.  If the tribunal wanted to know whether a particular IFC
drawing was of a standard that could form the basis of
a shop drawing, which is one of the things that you
opine on, that is something that you consider is within
the scope of the instructions of your first and second
report, yes?
A.  Yes.
Q.  But not, for instance -- because you said yesterday in
your presentation, you haven't looked at delay, you
haven't looked at what you say are the granular aspects
of impact?
A.  That's correct.
Q.  You don't look, for instance, at what else that design
team might have had on its plate at that particular time
when the IFC came in?
A.  Which design team, sorry?  The JV's design team or?
Q.  Specon's shop drawing team.
A.  No, I don't address that, no.
Q.  You also don't look, therefore, at, if a shop drawing is
approved, what the site team is capable of doing with
that shop drawing at that point in time.  That's not
something that --
A.  I didn't look at that.
Q.  -- is within your instructions.
So if the tribunal wanted to know the actual impact,
they would need to look at the IFC to shop drawing link
you look at, but then the other two things we just
talked about, what the Specon design team itself is
capable of doing and what the site team is in fact
capable of doing, and those are not things that you have
considered?
A.  I would probably say we would have to look at a lot more
than that to understand the impact.  I think the
timesheets would record who was doing what.
Q.  That's your instructions for your two design reports.
Can we just look at the process through which you put
them together.
Your first two reports were before witness
statements were filed.  I think the first rounds of
witness statements came in September 2024?
A.  I believe so.
Q.  The second round came in November or thereabouts.
Now, you do identify the sources of information you
have relied on in you reports.  Perhaps you could look
at C7-18, which is your first report, paragraph 2.7.
You identify here two sources of information.
Firstly, documents that you have been provided with and
then discussions that you've had with members of
Specon's staff, and then you specify a meeting that you
had with Mr Grgurev and Mr Al Taki on 9 February.
A.  Yes.
Q.  You say that you have relied upon information during
this meeting; wherever you have relied upon it, you have
identified it?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Just for my own understanding, because I couldn't find
any references to Mr Grgurev or Mr Al Taki in the
report, but there are instances where you say things
like, "I understand from discussions with Specon ..."?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Those are references to this meeting, are they?
A.  I would say yes, although I don't recall the detail.
Q.  Because you say here, where you have relied upon
information discussed during this meeting, you have
identified it?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Let's look at an example at C7-46 at subparagraph j):
"I understand from discussions with Specon that in
or around August 2018 ..."
The following things happened?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Is that an understanding that you got from that
discussion that you had with these two gentlemen on that
day in February?
A.  I would say yes, on account of, from memory, I think
that was the one and only meeting that I had with
Specon.  So anything I picked up in that discussion
would have gone back to that meeting.
Q.  I see.  So we are to take references to discussions with
Specon to that meeting with these two gentlemen?
A.  I think that would be fair.
Q.  There are about 10 or so instances where you say, you
have this formulation of, "I understand with discussions
with Specon ..."; I just want to understand what those
discussions were.
A.  Yes.
Q.  The second source of information that you list is
documents appended at appendix 2, which is -- if we go
back, appendix 2 is at C8-27.
We have this over a few pages, you have got exhibit
numbers, BH-1, 2 and so on and so forth?
A.  Yes.
Q.  As I understand it, this is a subset of information that
was supplied to you, but the subset that you considered
relevant for your report; is that correct?
A.  Yes.
Q.  From the larger data set that was provided to you, was
it you that whittled it down to these items that you are
identifying here or was it someone else that did it for
you?
A.  This would have been my work.  This is the documents
that we whittled down to be what we considered to be
relevant to the investigation, or tied to the
investigation.
Q.  You reviewed the entirety of the data set of documents
given to you?
A.  We flicked through many, many, many documents, as we do
on any investigation, and we identify what we think is
relevant.
Q.  What criteria did you use to identify the documents that
you say you relied upon?
A.  The process of investigation starts with the statements
of claim, the statements of defence, the pleadings,
these home in on key documents which lead us down
a trail to find other documents.  It's not very
complicated.  It's an investigative trail to find those
documents that are referred to and we use to form our
opinion.
Q.  One of the features of your first report, which you say
is a general report, is you referred to very, very few
shop drawings?
A.  Yes.
Q.  In fact, I think there's only three or four shop
drawings that you referred to.  You referred to the
register, you take a sort of statistical approach.
I wanted to understand why that was.  An explanation
could be that those were the three or four shop drawings
that you considered to be relevant.  Or an explanation
could be that you just didn't have time to do a deeper
review?
A.  It's neither.  My instructions were to focus on IFC
design.

So I will talk about wild air.
I've been present in the hearing from the start, so
I know the tribunal has heard quite a bit about wild air

explain some of the key concepts.
I should say I am a mechanical engineer.  I do
specialise in HVAC, air conditioning.  This is what I do
and what I have done for my whole career.
We have heard reference earlier to, in my first
report, my technical preamble.  Basically, this is an
extract of that, a shortened version, simplified, a bit
more visual, to try -- because I hope, what I'm trying
to do, if the tribunal can understand some of these key
concepts then it will be really helpful for
understanding the evidence on wild air.
So I would invite you to consider a glass of water.
That glass of water has a capacity and it can have more
or less water in it.  In this analogy, this represents
a molecule of air.  So it's quite simple to understand
that if that glass is half full, that would represent
50 per cent relative humidity, and if that glass was
75 per cent full, et cetera.  That's what the relative
humidity metric is measuring, it's how full the air is
of water vapour relative to its capacity to hold
moisture.
The complexity comes because air at different
temperatures has a different capacity.  It varies with
temperature.  It increases with temperature and it
increases exponentially as you go up into higher
temperatures.  So the glass of water is not the same
size at different temperatures.
If I were to fill my glass of water that represents
22.5 degrees C, half full, so I have 50 per cent RH,
relative humidity, at that temperature; if I were to
pour that glass of water into the next glass of water
up, warmer, and I keep doing that, I pour that water
from glass to glass, once I get up to my glass of water
that represents 35 degrees C, I've still got the same
amount of water, all I've done is pour it from glass to
glass, but now the glass is only one-quarter full,
because the glass is larger.
I should state that these are drawn relatively
precisely as per psychometric analysis, I haven't just
drawn these randomly.
So 35 degrees, 25 per cent RH, is the same amount of
moisture content in the air as 50 per cent at 22.5, and
that's why it's relative humidity.  It's relative to the
temperature, and that's really important.
So if I were to take the largest glass, my 35 degree
glass of water, and I were to fill it half full, so
I have 50 per cent RH now at 35 degrees C, and I start
to cool it, what I'm doing is I'm pouring the water from
the large glass into progressively smaller and smaller
glasses.  I will reach a point where I pour the water
into the smaller glass and it starts to spill over,
because it no longer fits in that smaller glass, and
that is what we call the dew point, and that is -- the
water which spills over the sides represents the
condensation.  And that is because the air at that lower
temperature, it no longer has the capacity to hold that
level of moisture that it has at those higher
temperatures.
I have referred to the dew point quite a lot in my
report, it's a real important parameter.  In air
conditioning what we do is we continue to cool beyond
that dew point, we cool it down so we're pouring into
smaller and smaller and smaller glasses.  When I get
down to the end, the lowest glass, I have now spilled
lots of water each time I do that.  That's my
condensation that's come out of the air.  You can see
that by doing that, I actually remove, in this example
here, about, approximately, half the moisture that I had
in the air, simply by cooling.  And I should add, you
can't cool the air without doing this.  It's what
happens to air when you cool it.
The reason why we cool air down that cold in air
conditioning applications is, well, it's to remove the
humidity, but it's so that then when that air is mixed
back in the room, you see the dotted line where the
cursor is, normally we're trying to get conditions in
this sort of range, between 22 to 25 degrees C and we
want humidity, relative humidity around 50 per cent at
those temperatures.
If I didn't cool it down to here, I wouldn't be able
to achieve this, because I've got to get rid of that
excess moisture that I have in the air.
So, how do we do this practically.  We use, at least
in chilled water applications like this -- most
buildings here in Dubai are chilled water based -- we
bring cold water, very low temperatures, about
6.5 degrees in this case, through pipes and we bring it
to our equipment, which is essentially a metal box, and
within that we have a coil.  Our water passes through
the coil.  Then we blow the air across that coil and in
the process of doing that we cool the air.  The heat
effectively passes from the air into the water.
So I've got cold water going in at 6.5 and I've got
warmer water coming out; I've got warmer air going in,
blows over the coil and then I've got cooler air coming
out.  That is how air conditioning works.
But of course the other thing I have is condensate,
which is the moisture that I've removed from the air by
pouring into those smaller and smaller glasses, and that
should go into the drain.
Then how do we achieve a temperature in the room?
This is where the control system comes in.  We need
a thermostat, which allows us to select the temperature
we want to achieve, and then we can modulate two things.
We can modulate the airspeed using a fan and we can
modulate the water flow using a valve.  Those compare to
the temperature that has been selected in the room.  If
the room is too warm, we need more air and more water,
and if the temperature is right, those will start to
ramp down.
Now, we can never get more cooling than the maximum
which has been designed, and that's selected by the
designer and that will be selected for the worst day of
the year, with all the people in the room, with the
lights on, you know, you put in enough to cover for the
worst case.
Normally we're using the control system to modulate
down in order to just meet the loads which are in the
room.
Wild air.  What is wild air.  In wild air, we don't
have the control system.  So we cannot do that
modulation of the airspeed or of closing the valve.
It's just going.
You can set them at the beginning, and in Specon's
method statement they confirm that they plan to set the
fans all to 100 per cent and the pressure independent
control valve, PICV, the valve, also to 100 per cent.
So they were getting maximum cooling all the time, the
peak design flow cooling going through the units.
You have got no thermostat, so you can't measure the
temperature; you're just cooling, maximum, all the time.
So if we look at how that would operate in a room
scenario.  Take your guestroom.  You have got some loads
in the room coming from heat from people, if there's
occupants in there, or from the sun coming in through
the windows, or just heat transmitting through the
walls, and you always have a level of infiltration;
that's allowed for in the calculations.
So that air goes into our duct, goes to our fan
coil, which is the process I just described now, it's
blown across the coil, it's cooled and it's put back
into the room.  And you do this over and over again.
It's constantly recirculating.  And every time I do that
I'm pouring the air into the smaller and smaller
glasses, I'm cooling it and I'm dehumidifying it.
That's how this should work.
We also put in a bit of fresh air, a separate supply
of fresh air which comes to another machine effectively
doing exactly the same process.
The important thing is these temperatures on the
left here, the 6.5 and the 15.  We really want to
maintain those temperatures at all times.
What happens if I were to open a door or, for
whatever reason, I've allowed a load of heat into the
room or moisture or both.
Now I have a higher temperature in the room, I bring
that warmer, perhaps more humid air across the coil in
exactly the same way and I blow it across the coil,
I cool the air, I dehumidify within the capacity that
has been defined by my system and I supply it back into
the room.  It's exactly the same.
I still get my maximum cooling capacity that I have
determined from this machine, but I'm starting from
a different point.
So on my chart of glasses of water, I'm not starting
from the point where I expect to be, I'm starting from
a higher point.  So I will still cool the air and I will
still dehumidify the air, but I might not get down to my
ideal point first of all, but I'm still then supplying
cooled, dehumidified air back into the room, and I'm
reiterating this over and over again.
So if the temperature was 30 degrees, you might get
it down to 29, then sometime later 28, then to 27, and
that's what happens.  If you open a door and let hot air
in the room, the air conditioning is not redundant; it
just takes time to get back to where it needs to be.
If I left the door open permanently, or there was
some other factor, infiltration, whatever it might be,
it then becomes a question of which is greater: the
capacity of my equipment, or the incoming gain of that
infiltration.  You would need to assess which of those
two is more powerful.
What we can see from the evidence here is this
scenario was what was happening.  I can't say, I don't
know, for how long, but I know it was at least happening
for several months across 2021.
What you can see on here is the chilled water
temperatures are well away from where they should be.
I think when you're looking at issues with HVAC as an
engineer, if you're diagnosing the problem, the chilled
water temperatures are like the vital signs, it's the
key parameter you want to check.
Looking at this, honestly that's a very sick system.
11 and 13.5, that's a very low -- what we call delta T,
the difference between two temperatures.  It should be
9 degrees.  That's 2.5.  And the capacity of the system
is directly proportional to that delta T.
So, what would happen in this scenario.  If you had
some infiltration coming in or if you had just some
normal heat gains in the space, you'd still do the same
thing.  You'd take them -- the duct will take it back
into the machine, it will blow it across the coil, but
now, instead of 6.5 degrees, my coil is not cold --
well, it's still cold but it's not as cold.  It's now
So I don't have the ability to do my various pours
of my glasses of water, I might be able to only do one
pour.  And because I can't get it down cold, I never get
that level of de-humidification that I would if the
water was colder.
So I'm still recirculating, I'm still cooling and it
will have an effect, but it's significantly degraded on
how it should be if everything was working correctly.
I know we've heard a bit about Empower, so I just
want to talk about that.  Empower are the district
cooling provider.  They are the ones who actually make
the water cold.  They're the ones who bring it down to
the temperature so that we can circulate it at
6.5 degrees.
In a project which has district cooling, which many
do here in Dubai, that's done offsite.  That's done in
a centralised plant and then it's distributed, that
chilled water is distributed to various buildings.
Normally one plant will do lots and lots of plots, it
won't just be one building.  I don't actually know in
this case how many buildings or how many plots the
Empower plant is serving.
But the way that works is another heat exchange
process.  It's very similar to the one we looked at
before, but this time, instead of water to air, it's
water to water.  They don't mix, they just go into
a heat exchanger.  There's no physical mixing, but the
heat is transferred between the two.
So what Empower is do they will always supply you at
a fixed temperature, 5.5 degrees C, and that's really
important for them.  They don't vary that.  They give
you that chilled water.
Then, on the secondary side, the building owner,
it's incumbent on them to make sure that they return the
water at 15.5 degrees C.  And that happens because you
are modulating your controls to make sure the right
amount of heat is passed into the water to keep that
temperature constant.
As long as you do that, everything is fine with
Empower, it'll all work as intended.
The issues with Empower begin when you don't do
that, which is obviously what was happening here.
If, for whatever reason, you're not achieving your
delta T, your 15.5 degrees on the return, the reason for
that is because there's not enough heat being taken out
of the system.  There's not enough load, or too much
water being pumped for the load.
So what you want to balance is the amount of heat
you're taking out of your spaces going into the water to
keep that return temperature high.
In this scenario Specon actually didn't have enough
load in the rooms and because they were pumping lots and
lots of water and not enough heat is being taken out
into that water, the return temperature comes back lower
than it should be.
So what do Empower do in this scenario?  Empower
react.  Empower are not the ones instigating the process
here.  They react to the return temperature.  And
because the return temperature comes back low, they
reduce their flow.  Because they want to maintain the
delta T on their side.  It's absolutely critical for the
operation of Empower that they maintain that delta T
because all their plant and all their equipment is sized
for a 9-degree delta T.  So they want their return
temperatures to be high.
What they normally do is they will reduce the flow
if on your building owner side, there's any issues with
temperature on that side.  What they also normally do as
well is issue penalty, monetary penalties for scenarios
like this.
Then that has the effect on the secondary side,
because Empower are reducing their flow, it then affects
even more the supply temperature on the Specon side.  So
that's why that goes up even higher to 11.
So you can get into real problems with this sort of
scenario.  It's not an uncommon issue.  In the air
conditioning industry it's known as low delta T and it
is a problem.
But what determines it is the flow rate that was
being pumped by Specon.  That's the variable that you
can change to address this.
So in conclusion, I'm not here to talk about
facades.  I'm only here to talk about MEP.  It is
possible that facades, there was some infiltration
coming in through the facades.  I can't say to what
extent that was happening or not.
But what I can say, looking at this, is that the
performance of the wild air system was impacted, it was
degraded, not by infiltration, but by issues with
chilled water temperatures.  And that operating under --
under those conditions, the wild air system would not be
performing as intended and it would be likely to give
rise to a humid environment.
I want to stress that the two are not -- it's not
a cause and effect.  The infiltration is not causing the
issues with temperature.  Ironically, more infiltration
would actually help, because it would give more load
into the room -- in this scenario of a low delta T.  I'm
not suggesting more infiltration is a good thing.  But
in this scenario, more load into the room would have
increased the return temperatures and actually helped
with the issues with Empower.  So they are very two
separate things.
Then just finally, on maintenance, I know we have

We have heard about the request for maintenance

Moving on, pipe insulation.  I think we agree that

In terms of snagging, I agree to a certain extent

If we're talking about snagging that's going to be

If it's not dripping but it has the potential to

And of course, if you want to close ceilings, you

the IFC rev 2.

Presentation by MR BRADLEY
WITNESS:  So the purpose of my presentation today is to
discuss what is meant by and the importance of weightage
in the context of project programmes and progress
reporting in construction projects.
I want to discuss and compare the application of the
as-planned/as-built windows delay analysis methodology
between myself and Mr Coyne.  I want to provide my
observations and opinion on Mr Coyne's approach.
I also want to -- I will discuss the status of the
subcontract works at termination and provide
a comparison of my assessment of the status of works at
termination and Mr Coyne's assessment.
Finally, a summary of my opinion for each window of
my analysis.
These are the relationships that have been filed by
both experts and the bundle references, which I'm sure
you're familiar with.
So moving on, what is meant by weightage in the
context of project programmes and progress reporting?
If we assume with this simple example -- this is an
example, both 10 days in duration, two activities, and
both planned to be performed at the same time.
So in this simple example, what we can see here is
activity X and activity Y.  On the face of it, these
activities seem of equal importance, and without really
applying what we refer to as a weightage to each
activity, it's not possible to really understand from
the programme, the effort that is required to perform
the work for each of these activities.  So both
effectively, on the face of it, appear to require the
same effort.
The activities in the programmes for this project,
both the baseline and the programme updates, were
weighted with both man hours and cost.  So in simple
terms, what does that mean?  It means the number of man
hours required to perform each activity or task, but
also the cost or the value of the work performed under
each activity or task.
Now, why was that?  As discussed within my reports,
it was mandated.  In my opinion, it's not only good
practice but it was actually mandated within the
programming and reporting guideline, which mandated for
this project that a weighted progress measure system
should be adopted, and any progress S curves should be
weighted.
That's consistent with my experience, particularly
on a project like this where you have a programme with,
say, 50,000 activities.  It's important to understand
with a relative weightage applied to each activity that
you're able to understand the impact of each activity or
task on the overall project completion.  So not only in
my opinion is it good practice, but it was also mandated
for this project.
What we can see here is if I was to look at the
baseline programme in isolation, we can see here that
there's considerably more budgeted labour units assigned
to the hotel tower than there is on the residence tower.
So without even understanding what the subcontract scope
of works was, I can tell from the baseline programme
that there's clearly more work to be performed in the
hotel tower than there is in the residence tower.
That accords with my understanding of the scope of
work, wherein Specon's scope was quite limited within
the residence tower.  So what these budgeted labour
units are useful for is to give you an indication as to
where the most amount of work is at a given point in
time and the most amount of work remaining.
It was actually reported in that way by the JV
throughout the project.  As I say, it was mandated, but
if we look at their monthly progress reports, what the
JV reported against was, we can see here, man days.
We can see in October 2017, the cumulative planned
progress was just under 14 per cent, but the actual
progress was just under 6 per cent.  That's taking into
consideration the labour that was attributed to each of
the activities.
The programmes were also loaded with cost and again
the JV reported against cost on a monthly basis.  What
we can see here, this is like an earned value analysis.
What they were saying is in October 2017, they had
planned to earn just under 19 per cent progress, but
they had actually earned just under 13 per cent
progress.
Moving on to the application of the as-planned
versus as-built methodology and my approach.
Myself and Mr Coyne agree on the baseline programme
and we're also aligned in that we both split the project
into locations, such as the hotel podium, for the
purpose of our analysis.
In very simple terms, the approach that I have taken
is that I first consider the planned progress of the
subcontract works in each location from the agreed
baseline programme.  Within each window of my analysis
I compare the planned progress from the baseline with
the actual progress reported in the main contract
programmes.  So effectively what I'm comparing is
a like-for-like comparison and it's also the progress
that was reported within the JV's main contract
programme updates.
Having compared the planned progress with the actual
progress, I then measure the extent of delay to the
subcontract works in each location.
Having established the extent of delay to the
subcontract works in each location, I then refer to the
remaining budgeted labour units within each location to
get an indication of where the most amount of work is
remaining within each window of my analysis.
The reason I do that is because I'm understanding
basically where is the most amount of work remaining, to
form a view of the critical path.
The Society of Construction Law Delay & Disruption
Protocol states that the critical path may on occasion
be more reliably established by analysis of resource
data.  So what it says within the protocol is:
"... the critical path to completion may on occasion
be more reliably established through a practical
analysis of the relevant facts or by analysis of ...
resource data."
So there's nothing controversial about what I'm
doing.  As we can see here, the protocol states that,
yes, it can be reliably assessed.
Mr Coyne provides a statement within his report and
he appears to agree, to an extent, of my approach.  What
he states is:
"While labour units can provide a relative
comparison of the overall scale of one area of work
against another ..."
So that's effectively what I'm using them for.  I'm
using them for comparing how much work is in one area
compared to how much work is in the other area.
Mr Coyne goes on to say that:
"... and could be used as a potential indicator of
criticality as part of a wider analysis..."
Again, that's exactly why I'm applying the budgeted
labour units, because I'm trying to, now, with the
critical path within the project -- which is the
residence towers, external works, townhouses, podium,
hotel tower -- effectively what I'm doing is I'm relying
on these budgeted labour units to tell me where in the
project is the most amount of work remaining.
Now, whilst Mr Coyne appears to agree to, I'd say,
a large extent of my approach, he states within his
reports that he disagrees with my over-reliance on the
budgeted labour units.
Mr Coyne provides some examples within his reports
which relate to the budgeted labour units, to very
specific -- at activity levels.  What Mr Coyne states
is, look, these budgeted labour units at these activity
levels appear to be incorrect or inconsistent with the
duration.
Some of those I have discussed with Mr Coyne's
assistant and we identified that, for example, the
example he provided was because we were relying on
different baseline programmes for the rev 7.  I agreed
with him, yes, that it did seem like an example of an
inconsistency, but it was subsequently updated in later
programme updates.
Mr Coyne also quite rightly points out that there
are some budgeted labour units -- some activities
without budgeted labour units assigned to them within
the programmes, and I would agree.  For example, if you
look at the activity IDs in the rev 6, rev 7 and rev 8,
there are some activities that do not appear to have
budgeted labour units assigned to them.  Now, I have
been through all of them and they appear to be sort of
marking the completion of works, et cetera, or
predominantly located to the basement, the podium and
townhouses, which are areas that neither experts
consider critical.  But the point is that the budgeted
labour units in my view are very useful in the wider
sense to sort of understand where the most amount of
work is.
Yes, I would completely expect there to be some
inconsistencies on the budgeted labour units at an
activity level simply because there's 50,000 activities
within the programme and these are all subject to manual
input, so I would expect to see some inconsistencies in
some activities.
In summary, in my opinion, considering both the
extent of delay to the subcontract works in each
location and the amount of remaining subcontract works,
in my view, is a commonsense assessment, a commonsense
way of assessing the critical path.
This is an example of window 1 of my analysis, so
what we can see here in window 1 of my analysis is that
having assessed the delay to each location, I can see
that the delay to the residence towers was significantly
greater -- or not significantly greater, but greater
than the delay to the hotel tower.
So I don't form an opinion on criticality purely on
the extent of delay.  I then go on and consider, well,
how much work is remaining in each area, and I do that
by reference to the budgeted labour units that are
remaining.  And I can see here that there's
significantly more work remaining in the hotel tower
than there is in the residence towers.
So I conclude at window 1 of my analysis that the
hotel tower's critical, even though the extent of delay
is less than in the residence towers.
Moving on to Mr Coyne's application of the
as-planned versus as-built windows methodology.
In very simple terms, again, this is my
understanding of Mr Coyne's approach, the first thing
Mr Coyne does, like I have done, is consider the planned
progress of the subcontract works performed in each
location from the agreed baseline programme.  So that is
agreed between the experts.
What Mr Coyne does to assess actual progress is he
compares the planned progress from the baseline
programme with his assessment of progress, referenced to
the number of approved work inspection requests from the
work inspection request log.
The first reservation I have with Mr Coyne's
approach in this regard is that it's not a like-for-like
comparison.  He is comparing planned progress in the
programme with progress from the number of approved work
inspection requests.  They are two completely -- sources
of data.
In very simple terms, what Mr Coyne appears to
assume is that if 40 per cent of the total number of
work inspection requests are approved, then this equates
to 40 per cent of progress of the subcontract works.
And in the next few slides I'll explain why I disagree
with that.
Now, having done, in much the same way as I've done,
but by relying on different records, what Mr Coyne then
does to establish a critical path, he applies what he
refers to as a remaining duration analysis, which is
effectively he projects within every window which
location of the project is in his opinion going to take
longer to complete.
So, moving on to Mr Coyne's reliance on the number
of approved work inspection requests.  As I sit here
today, it's still unclear to me exactly how many work
inspection requests were approved pre-termination and
post-termination for Specon's subcontract works, and
I say that because the Aconex system which I had access
to contains just under 94,000 work inspection request
records up to the point of termination.
Mr Coyne has provided a log of the work inspection
requests that he relies upon.  His log contains 92,000
work inspection requests, but that's up to completion of
the subcontract works post-termination.
So there appears to be a disconnect in the work
inspection requests in Mr Coyne's logs and the work
inspection requests that I have had access to on Aconex.
When I filter Mr Coyne's log that he provided for
approved work inspection requests, I note that his log
contains 47,445 work inspection requests.  I understood
from SBJV's fact witness Mr Hijazi, that he stated
within his fact witness statement that the log that they
maintained contained 50,978.
Having read the transcript, I understand he was
asked about this, but couldn't explain the disconnect
between his log and Mr Coyne's log.
Now, in some correspondence between the legal teams
during the preparation of the expert reports, Mr Coyne's
instructing legal team said that there were roughly
60,000 work inspection requests.
The first reservation I have with Mr Coyne's
reliance upon the work inspection request is that it's
not exactly clear to me how many there is and whether
his source of data is actually accurate in the first
instance.
This is an example from Mr Coyne's report as to
exactly how he assesses progress.
What we can see here is what I understand Mr Coyne
does is he simply counts the number of approved work
inspection requests and then adds in incremental
progress to each work inspection request as he
progresses.
As the number of approved work inspection requests
increases, the incremental progress that he assesses
also increases as well.
In my view, why is Mr Coyne's reliance on the number
of work inspection requests to assess progress
unreliable?
A work inspection request only confirms when the
works have been approved by the engineer.  A work
inspection request does not record when the works have
commenced.  A work inspection request does not record
the progress of the subcontract works after the
commencement and prior to the approval of work
inspection request.
A work inspection request doesn't even record when
the subcontract works are completed, only when they have
been approved.
As discussed previously, Mr Coyne assumes that if
40 per cent of the total number of work inspection
requests are approved, then this equates to 40 per cent
completion.
I provide examples within my second report from the
work inspection requests from Mr Coyne's log.  One
example I show is that one work inspection request is
for a mock-up of a light switch in the basement and the
other example I show is for the installation of HVAC
ducting within four hotel rooms.
The amount of work performed under each work
inspection request is clearly not equal.  However, my
understanding is that Mr Coyne treats every work
inspection request as being equal.
Mr Coyne states in his second report that it is not
practical for a weightage to be applied to each work
inspection request.  I would agree with that.  I would
agree that due to the significant number of work
inspection requests, that it's not practical to do that.
It would be most likely an impossible task.
But the issue I have with that is if you cannot
apply a weightage to a work inspection request, how can
you confirm that 40 per cent of the work inspection
requests equates to 40 per cent of the work's progress?
Now, in my view, by adopting this approach of
counting the number of approved work inspection
requests, Mr Coyne is never considering works which are
in progress throughout the project at any given time.
This is a huge project with subcontract works being
performed throughout the basement, the podium, the
residence towers and the hotel towers.
A significant portion of this work would not yet be
subject to a work inspection request, which means these
works -- the works which are in progress and which have
not been approved through a work inspection request will
not be recognised by Mr Coyne in his assessment of
progress.  In my view, what that means is that Mr Coyne
is consistently underestimating the progress of the
subcontract works at any given point.
It's also important to note that Mr Coyne's approach
could not have been applied contemporaneously, neither
during the project nor at the time of termination.  The
reason why that is is because you would have to wait
until you complete all of the subcontract works to
understand what 100 per cent is, to go back at any given
point in time to understand what percentage you were at
at that given time.
So moving on to Mr Coyne's remaining duration
analysis to determine the critical path.
Mr Coyne provides some explanation which I have
extracted from his reports.  Effectively, what Mr Coyne
explains is that the remaining duration analysis
determines the number of projected days to complete
each area.
So effectively, what he's saying in simple terms is
at any given point in his analysis, he's going to
project how long each location is going to take to
complete.
He provides a very theoretical example within his
report.  He says if the planned duration was 100 days
and the works were 25 per cent complete, then the
remaining duration would be 75 days.
The first reservation I have with that is that it
appears to be very much a pro rata arithmetical
calculation.  But the second reservation and issue
I have with that is that when Mr Coyne is talking here
about -- referring here to this 25 per cent, that's his
assessment of progress from the number of approved work
inspection requests.
Effectively, what he's relying upon and what
underpins his remaining duration analysis to determine
the critical path is his assessment of progress at every
point.  That is from the number of approved work
inspection requests which, in my view, is unreliable.
Mr Coyne also confirms that.  He states that the
accuracy of his remaining duration analysis is dependent
upon his assessment of progress.
In my view, if his assessment of progress is
unreliable, it follows, in my view, that the remaining
duration analysis which is underpinned by the progress
that he has assessed from the work inspection requests,
is also unreliable.
This is an example of Mr Coyne's remaining duration
analysis for window 2 from his report.
What Mr Coyne is showing here is that when he
considers the progress in the main contract programme
updates, he says: well, according to the progress in the
programme, both the podium and the hotel tower here are
pretty much forecasting to complete at the same time.
In my view, this is a much more reliable source of
information because, as discussed, the programmes
account for works which have not yet been approved.
So it's taking into account all of the incremental
progress of works which are underway but not yet
approved.
So what Mr Coyne effectively states -- and I agree
with -- is that both the podium and the hotel tower were
critical.
If we were to apply Mr Coyne's remaining duration
analysis to the programme, what this would show is that
the podium and the hotel tower were effectively almost
concurrently critical throughout the project duration.
Mr Coyne then performs the same exercise of
a remaining duration analysis, but this time it's with
the introduction of his assessment of progress from the
work inspection requests.
What Mr Coyne effectively does is he says: okay,
well, I'm going to re-forecast the remaining duration
based upon my own assessment of progress from the number
of approved work inspection requests.
What we can see here is that that significantly
changes the forecast completion date for both the podium
and the hotel tower.
What effectively Mr Coyne is forecasting is that the
podium will complete 11 months before termination and
the hotel tower will complete 13 months before
termination.
Now, two key points or observation from this is that
it's not until such time as Mr Coyne introduces his
assessment of progress from the number of approved work
inspection requests as the forecast remaining durations
change significantly for each location.  However, we
know that neither the hotel tower or the podium were
100 per cent complete at termination which means that,
in my view, these are theoretical projections at any
given point in time in Mr Coyne's analysis.
Moving on to -- Mr Coyne, within his report, when he
refers to criticality, he talks about -- in my view, he
treats the podium as a sort of broadbrush.  He says MEP
first and second fix works in the podium.
In my view, I disagreed with that approach.  The
reason I say that is because we know in the first
instance that there were significantly more subcontract
works in the lower ground level, ground level and
level 2 of the podium.  In fact, the subcontract works
in level 1, 3 and 4 of the podium were quite minimal.
So in my view, as a minimum, the critical path
within the podium could have been narrowed down to
a specific level.
What I would also say is that the subcontract works
in the hotel tower and residence tower were quite
typical and consistent throughout those towers.
The podium is, in effect, a series of very different
projects.  What I mean by that is that every area -- for
example, you may have heard of the All Day Dining.  This
is a huge restaurant area on level 2.  The spa and gym
and lower ground level, these are huge areas within
the podium.
Each of these areas had their own provisional sum
package, their own IFC package, their own fitout
subcontractors.
In my view, they're all very different and must be
treated differently and should be -- the critical path
should be narrowed down on account that these areas all
progressed at significantly different rates and were all
impacted by significantly different issues.
For example, we know that the spa and gym went
through significant redesign.  We know that the modern
Peruvian restaurant, there were issues with the fitout
subcontractor, et cetera.  So in my view, the critical
path should have been -- could have been and should have
been narrowed down.
This is an extract of what was reported
contemporaneously by SBJV within their multi-progress
reports.
I didn't have access to these in the preparation of
my analysis or my first report.  But when I received
them, I could see that effectively what the JV were
saying in the period from September 2019 to
October 2020, was effectively these specific areas
within the podium are on the critical path.
So the JV, at the time, were narrowing the critical
path down to specific restaurants.  We see the Peruvian
restaurant, podium, spa and gym, Persian restaurant,
British restaurant.  These are the areas which I have
also identified as being critical within my analysis.
If you look at the critical path discussion which
underpins these, there's a common theme that what's on
the critical path is the design and issues with fitout
subcontractors, et cetera.
So you can tell from even the JV's own discussion
which underpins this, that actually there was a lot of
very different -- there was different issues impacting
the different areas.
Not only did the JV report specific areas within the
podium as being on the critical path, I also note that
retrospectively, they also narrowed the critical path
again down to very, very specific areas within the
podium.
Again, I didn't know until quite recently, from
supplementary agreement number 3, that the SBJV had
received a full extension of time.  That only became
apparent to me during this hearing.
This extension of time claim number 4 wasn't
available to me during the preparation of my first
report.  But what we can see here is that, again, what
the JV were doing retrospectively was narrowing the
critical path or what they refer to as the dominant
delay to the project's time for completion to areas
again such as the spa and gym, All Day Dining, Persian
restaurant.
These areas just provided a comparison with my
opinion.  We can see, for example, I identify in
window 2 of my analysis, the spa and gym being critical.
We can see here in window 3 of my analysis, I see the
Persian restaurant and the All Day Dining as being
critical areas within the podium.
However, in summary, Mr Coyne doesn't narrow the
critical path within the podium.  In my opinion, it
could have and should have been done.
Moving on to the status of subcontract works at
termination.
Both experts have provided their assessment of the
status of the subcontract works at termination.
My assessment is from SBJV's main contract
programme.  So this is their programme which -- sorry,
the JV's programme which recorded that the subcontract
works were 89 per cent complete on 1 November 2021.
That's three weeks before termination.
The reason I have relied on that programme is
because the next programme actually postdates Specon's
termination.
SBJV's multi-progress report dated 30 November,
recorded that the subcontract works were 92 per cent
complete.  I understand that Arcadis, the employer's
cost consultant, certified that 94 per cent of the
subcontract value of the works had been certified.
When I performed my analysis from the programme,
I did a bit of a sanity check as to other
contemporaneous records.  I could see that I was broadly
in line with what was being contemporaneously reported
or certified at the time.
Mr Coyne provides two assessments of the status of
works at termination.  One in his first report where he
states that the subcontract works were 66 per cent
complete.
I understand that that is through his assessment of
progress from the number of approved work inspection
requests.  So what Mr Coyne, as I understand it -- or is
my understanding is that 66 per cent of the work
inspection requests were approved and that equates to
66 per cent of the subcontract works being complete.
Again, in my view, that's not taking into
consideration that works were ongoing at the time of
termination, but hadn't been subject to a work
inspection request approval.
I think in the second joint statement, I show some
examples from the work inspection requests which appear
to have been raised prior to termination, but approved
after termination.  So the works performed under those
work inspection requests would not be included in
Mr Coyne's assessment.
In joint statement number 2, Mr Coyne assesses the
subcontract works as being between 67 and 68 per cent
complete.  He elaborates on that.  I understand that he
still relies upon the number of approved work inspection
requests, but he also applies a sort of duration based
weightage to the programmes and does some analysis,
which I haven't been able to fully understand, but he
arrives at an assessment of between 67 and 68 per cent
complete.
In my view, if Mr Coyne's assessment is correct,
this would imply that Arcadis had over-certified the
subcontract works by 26 per cent.
When I look at that in a monetary value, that would
be based upon a contract sum of 608 million dirhams.
That would mean that Arcadis had over-certified by about
170 million dirhams.
It would also mean that if Mr Coyne's assessment is
correct, SBJV had over-reported the progress of the
subcontract works, both within their programmes and
their monthly progress reports by around 24 per cent.
So I think that's -- here is the summary of my
opinions, and I think I have pretty much run out of time
here.  So I'm not sure if the tribunal would want --
PRESIDENT:  We've got the summary.  That's very helpful.
The written summary is very helpful.
Thank you for that presentation, Mr Bradley.
Cross-examination by MR CATCHPOLE
MR CATCHPOLE:  Hopefully we can start with some
uncontroversial matters.
As you say in your presentation, you have agreed the
methodology to be adopted in the joint statements.
Broadly, it's as-planned versus as-built?
A.  That's correct, yes.
Q.  But there's a disagreement between you and Mr Coyne
about how that ought to be implemented in practice in
this particular dispute; is that right?
A.  Yes, mostly in respect to the as-built records that
we've relied upon and how we have determined the
critical path, I would summarise as being the two key
differences.
Q.  I apologise if this is too simple but, fundamentally,
you've got two very broad steps that you're concerned
about.  Is this right.  The first is to establish the
critical path to completion at any given point in time?
A.  Sorry?  Can you repeat?
Q.  The first task is to establish the critical path to
completion at any given point in time?
A.  Do you mean to establish the critical path of the
subcontract works?
Q.  Yes.
A.  Yes, yes.
Q.  That would include, for example, trying to establish
when and where that critical path might change,
over time?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Once you've established the critical path, you then
assess progress against events that are on that critical
path, over time?
A.  No, I would say you would have to assess progress before
you establish a critical path.
Q.  I'll come on to that.
Again, sticking with basics.  Sorry if this is --
could we go to F3, please.
I don't think this is controversial.  Criticality is
a function of the longest continuous sequence of work
remaining to be completed at any given point in time; is
that fair?
A.  Yes.
Q.  In other words, it's the necessary path through the
activities that are driving completion?
A.  Effectively, the critical path can be very simply
identified as the longest path through the project, yes.
Q.  Whereas, delay is a measure of past performance against
the original plan?
A.  Correct, yes.
Q.  When we look at critical path -- the SCL Protocol
definitions are helpful.  If we go to F3-67, "critical
path" is defined:
"The longest sequence of activities through
a project network from start to finish, the sum of whose
durations determines the overall project duration."
Pause there.  "Duration", if we go over the page,
please:
"Duration is the length of time needed to complete
an activity."
Is this fair.  What you're concerned to do, to
establish the critical path, is to establish the
duration of those activities which are linked in
a sequence which are driving completion of the project?
A.  What was the question?  Sorry?
Q.  You agree that in establishing the critical path, what
you're concerned to establish is the future durations,
likely durations of the activities on the longest path
to completion?
A.  Yes, yes.
Q.  So that is again, unsurprisingly, concerned with the
time that is required to complete those activities; is
that right?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Obviously we are going to talk about methodology for
establishing criticality in due course.  But one of the
issues you have identified just in the slides that you
have gone through, is the issue of weightage and the
risk -- I think you identify that incorrect weightage in
programmes can lead to over-reporting of progress?
A.  Sorry.  You say I say that?
Q.  Yes.  Do you not recall saying that?
A.  I don't recall saying that, no.
Q.  Oh, right.  Okay.
Could we please -- we'll leave it.
Would you agree with me, however, that cost, for
example, reporting against costs can if the weighting is
wrong, lead to an over-reporting of progress?
A.  I think if you look at my presentation and the two
S curves that I provide for October 2017, what you can
see is that in those two S curves which were in the
October 2017 progress report, the earned value in
respect to cost was I think around 18 per cent, whereas
the progress in respect to labour was significantly
less.  That's typical of what I would expect to see, is
that it's an unreliable method to assess progress to the
project.
Q.  What is?
A.  Against cost.
Q.  Unreliable because?
A.  Simply because if you have a piece of equipment, a high
value piece of equipment to be installed, and that high
value equipment is recognised and installed, it can skew
the progress, in my view.
Q.  Very often, what you find in value type systems is that
not improperly, a contractor will be effectively front
loading the payments to get the costs in before they do

A.  I wouldn't necessarily say "front loading".  I would say
that, you know, you can't necessarily just have
equipment delivered to site, because you have to store

so you can't -- the equipment must arrive on site as

Q.  Let me illustrate it.  L5294, please.
This was one of the few internal presentations
I think to the board at Specon that we had.  It's from
June 2017.
If we look, first of all, at tab 1.4, this is -- if
we can zoom out a little bit -- based on the rev 6
programme, this is their expected baseline programme
with the expenditure of man hours?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Do you see that?
A.  Yes.
Q.  Then if we go to 1.5, please, zoom out again, please --
sorry, that's 1.6.  Can we go to 1.5, please.
This is the curve they have for -- if you zoom out,
please -- their expected billings based on the programme
that they are putting together.
And if we could please look at our opening, N3-23.
Sorry, it's the presentation, not the opening.  It's
slide 23.
We have taken those two curves from the Specon
report.
If we go to the next slide, please.
You see what that shows is that Specon were
positively planning to effectively earn in advance of

A.  I can see a curve that shows planned earned value.  Is

Q.  The point is that the risk -- what it's showing,
whatever they have done -- and it's common, I imagine,

They have loaded the baseline programme, certainly
with costs, to ensure that they get paid in advance of
the work; is that right?  If this graph is right.
A.  From my understanding of the baseline programme, there

Q.  It's the weighting.  They're getting the money in before

Q.  If that was being used, that sort of earned value as the

A.  Yeah.  I mean, as I discussed, there is not -- once they

Q.  You would appreciate also that Arcadis are -- their

A.  Do you mean certify the works?
Q.  Yes.
A.  I understand that that was their role, yes.

A.  No.  That's --

Q.  As I understand their case, they're actually saying
